In addition to the above elements, Shell also employs specific prevention measures that are incorporated into the process operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:

General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures include:

-Process engineered and constructed (as a minimum) in accordance with recognized industry and company standards.
-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety/relief valves). -Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams.
-Computerized monitoring and control of process operation.
-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems.
-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, analyzers, and safety devices.
-Limited facility access.
-Regular safety meetings and safety awareness programs.
-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits.

General Release Mitigation includes

-Automatic (ESD and thermal actuated) and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity. -Strategically located valves to isolate leaks.
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release with auto-shutdown functions.

General Emergency Response includes:

-Emergency alert system.
-Periodic emergency training for employees.
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies.
-Emergency drills with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, Providence Terminal Butane Process complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition

to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) and Emergency Action Plan (EAP) are in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Providence Fire Department and Providence Emergency Management Agency & Office of Homeland Security.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

As this is an RMP for a project that has yet to begin operation, no incidents involving the RMP covered process have been documented.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Response actions are coordinated with the Providence Fire Department. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) and Emergency Action Plan (EAP) are in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. Shell - Providence Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's instructions and recommendations. In the event of an emergency involving the Providence Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the New Haven Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire response capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Providence Fire Department and Providence Emergency Management Agency & Office of Homeland Security. The Providence Fire Department regularly participates in training and exercise sessions for this Facility.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Shell is continually striving to make the Providence Terminal the s

afest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community. In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Shell looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Shell - Providence Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. Providence Terminal is an MTSA regulated, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Providence, RI. The Terminal handles and stores gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

Shell - Providence Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Shell believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding EHS performance is of paramount importance.

Providence Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Shell promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Shell has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The primary function of Providence Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as Program level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances are identified. By virtue of the flamma

ble effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Shell - Providence Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors/visitors which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Providence Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by railcar and blended directly into atmospheric gasoline tanks. No fixed butane storage is included as part of this process. Access to the Providence Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

Shell's accidental release prevention programs along with emergency planning and response programs allow affective management of the hazards posed by butane to our employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at Providence Terminal:

1. Employee Participation
2. Process Safety Information
3. Process Hazard Analysis
4. Standard Operating Procedures
5. Operator Training
6. Contractors
7. Pre-startup Safety Review
8. Mechanical Integrity 
9. Hot Work Permits
10. Management of Change
11. Incident Investigation
12. Emergency Response
13. Compliance Audit
14. Trade Secrets
